Radio Buttons

Radio buttons are used when a user is presented with two or more options, and must select only one option.

Examples

${require('html-loader?interpolate!../../partials/toggles.html')}
Would you like to be added to our mailing list? *
Would you like to be added to our mailing list?
Would you like to be added to our mailing list? (Optional)
Would you like to be added to our mailing list?

Guidelines

  • Radio buttons should be used when you have a small number of response options, ideally 7 or less. For longer lists, use a dropdown.
  • Radio buttons should be used when a user is unfamiliar with the available options, or when the options available necessitate being compared against one another at the time of selection.

Documentation

Bootstrap Documentation

Modifiers

Class Description
.uxf-is-required add class to a legend element to apply required styles
.uxf-is-optional add class to a legend element to apply optional styles
.radio-inline add class to label element surrounding input in order to inline radio inputs
.custom-control-inline add class to .custom-radio element surrounding input in order to inline radio inputs

Javascript

To validate radio buttons, use the jQuery Validation library included in UXFrame Plus and add .uxf-jquery-validate to the .uxf containing element.

Convert from UXFrame v1 to v2

  1. Remove .error class on form elements, and add .has-error class to parent .input-box elements.
  2. Remove the div immediately after the input[type="radio"] label label.
  3. Remove the .horizontal class from ul.radio-list elements, and add .radio-inline to the radio button labels inside the ul.radio-list element
  4. Change .input-box to .form-group.
  5. Change ul.radio-list to div.form-group. Remove the li elements encapsulating the radio buttons.
  6. Surround input[type="radio"] elements with their respective label tags. Put the input label text right before the closing label tag.
  7. Add .uxf-jquery-validate to the .uxf containing element if using validation.
